Used to also have issues where messages often were delivered minutes or hours later despite both phones having Internet - that seems to have improved but current version drops calls exactly every 10 min. Edit: now calls don't work at all. Splendid!

Hassles false notifications constantly. Annoying and tacky marketing. I cannot get app for my tablet. If they would stop hassling me to do this review and get a chance to get to test it out fully, I may be giving it a 5 star rating. Other than that, I still need to run my default messing app and that app has access to my network and possibly still can see what is going on with my data even if it is encrypted. I still need to see how that goes. I have a bachelor in IT risk management and Cyber security and really need more time to give a better rating. Otherwise, so far it seems like a good app for the most part on it's functionality. tablet

Review.author: Clara Todd
Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: On the whole I really like it, a tidy UI and simple to use, as well as secure and encrypted between two signal users. You need to be on wifi/mobile data to be able to send messages to a friend you've established signal contact with. it won't tell you that the message can't be or hasn't been sent. Get in the habit of checking connectivity before sending, and decide if you want to use insecure SMS, as it's a simple enough switch on the send button. They've not got the UX case handled if your friend uninstalls or stops using it either, it needs to default back to SMS If it can be detected. It's also very fussy with the international phone number formats - even if your friend phones you so it's the number that is registered without you entering it by hand, you have to edit. But apart from that, it's great. Head and shoulders above anything else I've tried, plus secure.

Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: This is a small and tidy SMS application that will do everything you need it to do. It's fast, easy to use, and seamlessly handles real SMS (with those who don't have Signal) and secured messages. Personally, I prefer it to other leading SMS apps, even without the security asset. The main problem is that there are very few users. The only person I actually have secured messages with, I persuaded to download the application.

Review.author: Courtney Webster
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: Excellent texting app, the encryption is totally seamless, no user set-up required. Just want to acknowledge the uphill battle the devs have so marvellously won - not only is this the most secure texting app on the market, but it competes with and exceeds most other texting apps. Download it, you won't be disappointed. Update: the encrypted calls lag by about three seconds. If your first concern is a private conversation, it'll do, but it's not really a drop-in replacement for regular calls.

It's initial set up is simple, you don't need a degree in cryptography to use it and it's code is under constant review to make sure it's secure.

It seems to function very well and makes good calls too (if those are encrypted in some way that's awesome but I don't know if they are). I like the idea of the end to end encryption and I hear this app does it the way they should but I'm not familiar enough with the tech to make a recommendation based on that. I think it has a good looking icon too.

There should be no excuse. How this has 5 stars is a testimony to fake reviews on the Google store.

Review.author: Duncan X. Simpson
Review.star: Rated 1 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Don't call yourself free.
Review.comment: Signal is free as in beer but not as in speech. It's open source, but the author goes after anybody who makes a port and uses the same name, logo, or their servers. This means if I create a better app as a port, it can neither be called Signal (although I doubt that would hold up in court) nor communicate with the original Signal app.

Review.author: Alan Gurling
Review.star: Rated 1 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: Was awesome until I realised this was causing me to NOT receive important security SMS messages. I have two-factor authentication for many accounts, and with Signal installed, I don't receive text messages from the providers. I have to send a SMS from another phone first, then request another code for Signal, and this stupid "hack" fixes the issue for a few minutes. After that, it stops receiving SMS from providers again. I have a Mi Fit that vibrates when I receive an SMS. It confirms that a SMS has arrived since it vibrates immediately when I request a cod, but nothing on Signal. This is a GLARING bug. What use is security if you can't use the app at all. :(

Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Gold Standard of Secure Private Messaging
Review.comment: Super easy to setup and use. End to end encryption is awesome and takes your mind off of having to self censor. Being able to use it as a complete sms app replacement is great. It has room to grow in functionality to other apps, such as BBM, which has nice features like being able to send multiple attachments per message. That being said there is no other app that brings this level of privacy in such an easy package. That's what makes this the gold standard at the moment.

Review.author: Kevin J. Wangler
Review.star: Rated 3 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: I like that it's secure, but it definitely has some drawbacks. Sometimes when I open Signal, it takes a while (several minutes, at least) for it to load in the names and pictures -- and while I wait, it just shows me the phone numbers. I hardly recognize any phone numbers, so I never know who sent what until it eventually loads the names. It does this on several other phones in my family, too. Secondly, it doesn't support Cell Broadcast, so when an emergency broadcast (e.g., Amber Alert or other alert) is sent out, I have to go back to the regular messaging app to view it. No reason Signal shouldn't be able to support CB.

More importantly: Signal seems to be incompatible with my desktop SMS application (Airdroid). Signal offers their own desktop messenger, but it only works with other signal users.

Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Seriously great, but not just yet awesome
Review.comment: Still a few stability issues on an Android Nexus 6, e.g. sometimes trying to call someone leads to the UI remaining half empty. It seems to happen when two people call each other at the same time. But it's not a bad issue. I can recover by killing the process. I also *really* wish there was a better way to transition when I need to factory reset my device; e.g. encrypted message backup and/or some transition key to cryptographically secure one's intent to reinstall or move to a different device.

My biggest gripe with the service is that I would love to see a true (non-chrome) web/desktop UI as well. I'm looking to replace the functionality of Google Hangouts, and apart from video calling, my most-missed feature is true cross-device access to the platform.

Therefore, the fundamental and necessary means to maintain our very humanity require defiance to protect. These self-evident truths should never be subverted, and those who help in our resistance against their suppression should be supported. Signal, and Open Whisper Systems represent those who provide us the tools to help ourselves to help each other.

Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Excellent for my usage
Review.comment: Here is what I like. I can receive text messages in the same app as signal messages. This made the transition for family members really easy. I can receive signal messages on my desktop. I can theme the colors and sounds. It even has a dark mode. Now I can do voice messages like WhatsApp. Plus it allows for secure messages amongst Signal users. It works well for me. It's not perfect, but it's close for my usage. I'd like to see improvements on backup/import (media and auto backup) and Google Now.

It would be interesting to send standard sms when the phone is not connected to the Internet, specially when you use Signal as your default sms/mms app. Nevertheless, it is an app with lots of potential.

Review.comment: Small-Sized, yet Robust and Snappy -- the Passphrase feature won't let you see beyond the Passphrase screen ! You see NOTHING inside Signal until you key in the PP. I'm sure you've encountered applock apps that are too slow and late to trigger that you're actually already in the app when suddenly you get "pulled backwards" away from what you're doing in there, backwards through a "threshhold" of a lockscreen that wasn't even there before, and then realize you needed to go through that lockscreen first !

Review.comment: My wife and I are testing signal out, using it for SMS as well as encrypted messages. I would like there to be better feedback for the sender in these cases (who is often unaware that the message has not been received) & an easy option to send an (unencrypted) sms if a message does not deliver. Security is important but reliability and transparencyoften more so.

Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: Good stuff. But remember to manually export your messages from within the app, if doing (eg) ROM flashing which requires wiping your phone. Signal doesn't use the Android system messages DB, so a normal ADB Backup won't save them. I learnt this the hard way and lost a couple of hundred messages! This also applies when switching back to another SMS app. Any SMS you sent using Signal won't be imported back into the system messages DB, so if you need them, you'll have to manually export/import them.

You will be my new favorite company.

Plus it syncs messages with the desktop version or other multiple devices you have. There is absolutely no reason for anyone on Android not to immediately install this. Improve your security and privacy today!

Review.author: Steve Sedlmayr
Review.star: Rated 1 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Encryption... for a price
Review.comment: Requires almost every permission on your device. Also imports all of your texts into a db... I guarantee you the original copies are still on whatever database they were already on. Then locks you out of the sms and phone apps on your device. No thanks. I wish we lived in an age when I could trust another 3rd party with my info. If not a straight NSA front, it won't be long before they infiltrate the company via the now-well-documented plethora of options available. I'd rather deal with the devil I know.

It's very frustrating because I want to use the Signal app, but now I have to use two apps for MMS and SMS. Signal to signal convos work great though

Review.author: Chuck Wells
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: This app would be terrific except for one problem. I have the phone sitting there with Wi-Fi or mobile, strong signal, and volume up. I am expecting my wife to send something but I get nothing. I grab the phone to look, only to find there is no notification. I open the app and suddenly it goes "bing!" and shows me a new message, sent "18 minutes ago". I was here the whole time. What happened? This keeps randomly happening. When this happens, FB messenger is not having any issue. I don't think there is a net issue. What's worse, it shows the message as received to the other person, so I think it went through, but its off in la la land somewhere deciding to show up a random amount of time later. Very bad for communicating, just causes arguments with people talking past each other, with no idea that they are getting delayed.

Review.author: David Pittman
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Better Encrypted Messaging App BAR NONE
Review.comment: Can't be more effusive in praise for this app or company. The nonprofit OWS keeps next to nothing about you or your conversations on their servers. Even better is the app can also handle your SMS/MMS too, serving as a fallback until someone in your contacts joins Signal. There's also a great desktop client so you can message securely from your laptop. One suggestion for improvement: raise SMS attachment size from 300kb!

Review.author: Strad Zhang
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Best Secured SMS
Review.comment: It's rated as one of the most secured texting apps. It also can be used to text people without this app making it the only SMS you need. The only downside is that there is not much user customization and no user guides at all. Another downside is that deleted groups don't really go away, which is a bit creepy. Don't believe me? Install the desktop version and you'll see the deleted groups. However it's still a 5-star app considering it's free.

Review.title: Almost perfect
Review.comment: Main issue is with phone calls. When a call pics up there is an annoying chime so you can't hear the other person at first. It also drops calls a lot. Messaging is limited in attachment abilities but not by too much. I still use this as my primary messages but not my primary calling app.

Review.author: Tim Taylor
Review.star: Rated 4 stars out of five stars
Review.comment: It's a good app, as such things go. I trust my conversations on here to be private far more than I trust other apps which have implemented Open Whisper, like Facebook and WhatsApp. It does bother me, however, that your account is tied to your phone number. Phone numbers are some of the most traceable identifiers on the planet, and would therefore seem to work against the concept of a totally private messaging experience. It feels like a different, more anonymous unique identifier would be possible.

Once that happened, plain sailing, and I can even send encrypted Cat Memes, which I'm counting as a victory.

But then I have hundred of other convenient options for secure communication (XMPP with OTR, GPG signed email, etc.). Encrypted SMS was the major feature of this app. And now it is removed. LOL! Also, sometimes the app does not receive messages. When I open the app after couple of days not using it, messages from past start arriving.

There is a Signal Chrome App is well such that you can message from your computer as well, significantly speeding up communication while at the computer. An all around amazing service made by awesome citizens!

Review.star: Rated 2 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Still a way to go
Review.comment: Tried Signal but found that it was still pretty limited in basic functionality. Also, receiving messages were frequently delayed. Often I wouldn't receive a message until I opened signal and then got a whole lot of messages come in hours after they were sent. Can't really send to multiple contacts without first creating a group. Can't include additional contacts when relying to a message. The privacy thing whilst nice, in reality is not useful because all my contacts refused to use it.

Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Truely Secure
Review.comment: This app is solid and works at 99.5% efficiency. It also prevents screen grabs from text, keeps no records of phone calls. And has auto destruct on messages sent to other phones, so they have a time limit before it disappears. I wish to donate money to this project! I combine this app with my paid subscription to Kaspersky for full complete protection from the evil Zionist-supremacist Mi6.

Stock messaging in iPhone and Android have accomplished this, I'm sure Signal can do it to make this a 5 star app.

She was given an iPad and was delighted to be able to text other Apple owners without much issue at all, but was frustrated at her inability to text Android users. A lot of apps that work across both operating systems are questionable, but this one is decidedly the least offensive when it comes to privacy and security. It works beautifully as well.

And provided there is no option to remove the +91 is a deal breaker as now I cant send sms to that number. 2.) When I tap on a number in a msg can I not get an option to send an sms that number in addition to just calling him?

Review.author: Benjamin Neider
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Gold Standard for Encrypted Messengers
Review.comment: I am a long-time user of this app and Signal is a great, easy-to-use encrypted messenger with continually expanding features that has a very good reputation amongst the FOSS and privacy-concerned communities. I have just a few requests for features to be added: (1) a doodling feature like is available on apps like Wire or iMessage, (2) encrypted video calls, and (3) the ability to like or edit messages already sent. I would be interested in knowing if OWS plans to implement these in the future and when.

The calling features between two people with the app aren't great, but it's free and a secure connection, so it's a trade-off. Took off a star for the so-so calling features, but overall it's a great secure alternative to Apple or Android stock texting apps.

Review.author: Karl Semich
Review.star: Rated 5 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Use this. Now.
Review.comment: There are a lot of well-marketed encryption solutions out there, but what most don't know is that these are generally not very strong, nor well-regarded by cryptography researchers. Signal is the real deal. The protocol is well-regarded and publically available, and considered a model when new standards for encrypted communication are discussed. I've read the spec and believe it to guarantee that both the servers themselves cannot read your messages, and that the client can prove they've been delivered.

Review.author: Nick Edwards
Review.star: Rated 3 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Privacy or Reliability, Not Both
Review.comment: As simple as that. Signal seems to take privacy to the point of deciding I myself can't view some messages sent to me, tossing them down the memory hole, never to be retrieved. I could somewhat understand this as a rather aggressive security measure, but only if the app deigned to let me read what I'm sent first. A glaring flaw in what is otherwise an excellent, indispensable tool. Also, it'd be nice to have a few more colours to choose from.

Review.author: Christian Xavier
Review.star: Rated 1 stars out of five stars
Review.title: Unreliable and Devs Refuse to Fix
Review.comment: This app has two issues 1 i can live with and one I cannot. 1) Messages won't send over WiFi. 2) when delivering messages the phone sometimes give delivery error messages that seem to be untrue. In my own testing the issues seem to be that the the app doesn't play well with iMessage. The Debug system they use can't capture the issue so for them it doesn't exist. Their answer is to turn off notifications for all message so I never have delivery confirmation. I say fix the app. They say no.
